How do I paint an open concept living area?

Painting an open-concept space can seem daunting because every wall is visible at the same time. The key is to create harmony while still giving each “zone” (living, dining, kitchen, hallway, etc.) a subtle identity. Below is a practical, step-by-step guide you can follow with products and tools you’ll find at Zava.  

——————————————————  
1. PLAN THE COLOUR SCHEME FIRST  
——————————————————  
1.1 Pick a unifying main colour  
• Choose one neutral or near-neutral hue (e.g., warm white, greige, soft taupe) that feels good in every part of the space and under all lighting conditions.  
• Test large swatches first—paint sample boards and move them around throughout the day.  

1.2 Add 1–2 accent colours  
• Accent walls or smaller architectural elements (columns, built-ins, the back of a breakfast bar) can get a deeper or contrasting colour.  
• Use the 60-30-10 rule: 60 % main colour, 30 % secondary, 10 % accent.  

1.3 Consider sheen strategically  
• Ceilings: flat or ultra-flat to hide imperfections.  
• Walls: eggshell or low-sheen for wipe-ability without glare.  
• Trim & doors: satin or semi-gloss for durability.  

(Products at Zava to check out: Zava Ultra-Flat Ceiling Paint, ZavaPro Interior Eggshell, ZavaTrim Water-Based Enamel.)  

——————————————————  
2. PREP THE SPACE  
——————————————————  
2.1 Empty & protect  
• Move furniture to the centre and cover with plastic drop sheets.  
• Tape off baseboards, windows, and any surfaces you don’t want painted with high-quality painter’s tape.  

2.2 Clean & repair  
• Wash walls with a mild TSP substitute to remove grease, especially near kitchens.  
• Fill holes or cracks with lightweight spackle; sand smooth once dry.  
• If there are glossy surfaces, de-gloss by lightly sanding or using a liquid deglosser.  

2.3 Prime where needed  
• New drywall, patched areas, or colour changes of two shades or more should be primed first.  
• ZavaPrime High-Hide Acrylic Primer blocks stains and gives even coverage.  

——————————————————  
3. “CUT IN” AND ROLL SYSTEMATICALLY  
——————————————————  
Open layouts rarely have stopping points, so work one full wall at a time:  

3.1 Cut in edges  
• Use a 50 mm (2") angled sash brush to paint a 7–10 cm (3–4") band along ceilings, corners, and trim. This wet edge prevents roller marks.  

3.2 Back-roll immediately  
• While the cut-in is still wet, roll the wall from top to bottom in overlapping “W” patterns. This blends the brush and roller textures.  

3.3 Maintain a wet edge  
• Always roll from an unpainted area back into the wet paint to avoid lap lines.  
• Work around the space in logical sections (e.g., start at one corner and move clockwise).  

——————————————————  
4. HANDLE ACCENT AREAS  
——————————————————  
4.1 Mark natural transitions  
• Use corners, bulkheads, columns or the underside of an open beam as crisp dividing lines.  
• Where no natural break exists, measure and snap a chalk line or use a laser level, then tape it.  

4.2 Paint accents last  
• Complete all main-colour walls first, let them dry, then tape off and paint accent walls/areas.  
• Remove tape while the accent paint is still slightly wet to avoid peeling.  

——————————————————  
5. FINISHING TOUCHES  
——————————————————  
5.1 Inspect under multiple lights  
• Walk around with lights on and off; check for missed spots or roller ridges.  
• Touch up while you still have wet paint in the tray for an exact match.  

5.2 Reinstall plates & hardware  
• Wait 24 hours before re-installing outlet covers or hanging artwork.  
• Cure time for most acrylic interior paints is about two weeks—avoid vigorous scrubbing until then.  

——————————————————  
TYPICAL MATERIAL LIST (all available at Zava)  
——————————————————  
• ZavaPro Interior Paint (colour & sheen of your choice)  
• ZavaPrime High-Hide Acrylic Primer  
• Quality 9-in. roller frame + 10–13 mm (3/8–1/2") nap microfibre covers  
• 50 mm (2") angled sash brush (nylon/poly blend)  
• Extension pole (1.5–3 m) for ceilings & tall walls  
• Sturdy 9-in. paint tray with disposable liners  
• High-tack painter’s tape (28- or 36-mm)  
• Plastic drop sheets & heavy-duty kraft paper  
• Lightweight spackle & sanding sponge (120-150 grit)  
• TSP-free wall cleaner & lint-free cloths  

——————————————————  
QUICK PRO TIPS  
——————————————————  
• If you must stop mid-wall, wrap the roller in plastic and lap the new coat over the last wet edge within 30 minutes.  
• Use natural daylight as much as possible when colour-matching.  
• Label leftover paint cans with room name and date; it helps for later touch-ups.  
• Keep a small “touch-up kit” (tiny can + mini roller) hidden in a closet for dings and scuffs.  

——————————————————  
SAFETY & CLEAN-UP  
——————————————————  
• Ventilate: open windows or use fans, especially when priming.  
• Wear a respirator or mask if you have sensitivities.  
• Clean water-based paint tools in warm, soapy water. Avoid pouring rinse water down storm drains—use a sanitary drain.  
• Dispose of empty cans according to local household hazardous waste rules (Zava stores provide recycling drop-off points in most regions).  

With a solid plan, good prep, and quality paint, an open-concept living area can look seamless and inviting while still letting each zone feel distinct. If you need colour cards, sample pots, or tool recommendations, just pop into your nearest Zava or chat with us online. Happy painting!

What's the best way to paint over old exterior paint?

Painting over existing exterior paint isn’t difficult, but good preparation is crucial if you want the new finish to last more than a season or two. Here’s a proven step-by-step process along with product and tool tips you can pick up at Zava or any well-stocked DIY store.

1. Inspect and test for lead (if the house was built before 1978).
   • Use an EPA-recognized lead test kit.  
   • If you confirm lead, follow local containment, sanding and disposal rules or hire a certified pro. (This keeps you legal and safe.)

2. Wash the surface.
   • A garden hose with a scrub brush will work, but a pressure washer (1,000–1,400 psi) speeds things up.  
   • Add exterior house wash or a TSP-substitute solution to remove chalk, dirt and loose contaminants.  
   • Rinse thoroughly and let everything dry at least 24 hours.

3. Remove loose paint.
   • Use a paint scraper, 5-in-1 tool or stiff putty knife on peeling and bubbling spots.  
   • Feather rough edges with medium-grit (80-120) sandpaper or a sanding sponge.

4. Deal with mildew or algae.
   • Treat any black, green or brown patches with a 3:1 water-to-bleach solution or a premixed siding cleaner.  
   • Rinse and allow to dry fully.

5. Sand glossy or smooth areas.
   • Scuff-sand previously glossy paint with 150-180-grit paper to give the new coat “tooth.”  
   • Wipe away dust with a damp rag or tack cloth.

6. Repair gaps, cracks and holes.
   • Fill nail holes or minor wood damage with exterior wood filler or epoxy filler.  
   • Caulk vertical seams, joints, and around windows/doors with paintable exterior caulk.  
   • Allow fillers/caulk to cure, then sand flush.

7. Prime bare or problem areas.
   • Spot-prime any exposed wood, metal, repairs or heavily chalked areas with a high-quality exterior primer (alkyd/oil or bonding acrylic).  
   • On badly weathered siding or if you’re making a drastic color change, consider priming the whole wall for best uniformity and adhesion.

8. Choose the right topcoat.
   • 100 % acrylic latex exterior paint is the workhorse for most climates—flexible, UV-resistant and easy cleanup.  
   • Opt for a satin or low-sheen finish on siding (hides imperfections) and semigloss or gloss on trim (easier to clean).  
   • Budget paints cover fewer square feet and often require a third coat; a premium line usually saves time and lasts longer.

9. Mind the weather window.
   • Ideal painting temps: 50 °F to 85 °F (10 °C – 29 °C).  
   • Avoid painting in direct, hot sun or when rain is likely within 24 hrs.  
   • Watch dew point: stop at least two hours before it is reached to prevent moisture on fresh paint.

10. Apply paint correctly.
   • Tools:  
     – Quality 2½–3″ angled sash brush for cutting in.  
     – 9″ roller frame with ⅜–½″ nap cover for smooth siding; ¾″ for rough/textured surfaces.  
     – Extension pole reduces ladder work and fatigue.  
   • Technique:  
     – “Cut in” around edges and trim first, then roll the field while the cut-in is still wet to avoid lap marks.  
     – Keep a wet edge; work in sections you can finish before moving on.  
     – Two thin coats trump one thick coat; allow proper recoat time (usually 4–6 hrs for latex).

11. Clean up and cure.
   • Latex: rinse brushes/rollers in warm soapy water.  
   • Oil/alkyd: clean tools with mineral spirits.  
   • Full cure time is 7–30 days, so go easy on washing or abrasion until then.

Quick shopping list (add/subtract to fit your project):
• Lead test kit  
• Exterior house wash or TSP substitute  
• Paint scraper, sanding sponges, medium and fine sandpaper  
• Exterior wood/epoxy filler, paintable exterior caulk & caulk gun  
• Exterior primer (bonding or stain-blocking)  
• High-quality 100 % acrylic latex exterior paint  
• 2½–3″ angled brush, 9″ roller frame, covers, extension pole, paint pails/trays  
• Painter’s tape, drop cloths, safety glasses, gloves, dust mask or respirator

Follow these steps and you’ll get a durable, professional-looking finish that should hold up 8–10 years, depending on climate and exposure. If you need product recommendations or color matching, stop by your nearest Zava—we’re always happy to help. Happy painting!

How do I paint over a heavily textured wall?

Painting a heavily textured wall isn’t difficult, but it does require a bit more prep work and the right tools. Follow these steps to get professional-looking results:

1. Inspect and repair
   • Look for cracks, nail pops, or loose texture.  
   • Fill holes or gouges with a lightweight spackle or joint compound.  
   • Sand the patched areas smooth once dry, but don’t try to sand down all the texture—just feather out the repair.

2. Clean the surface
   • Dust and cobwebs love textured walls. Vacuum with a brush attachment or use a dry paintbrush to knock off debris.  
   • Wash greasy spots (kitchens, kids’ rooms) with a mild TSP-substitute solution, then rinse and let dry.

3. Remove high peaks if necessary (optional)
   • If the texture is extremely sharp (e.g., aggressive “popcorn” or heavy knock-down ridges), knock off the very tips with a 120-grit sanding sponge or pole sander.  
   • Vacuum or wipe down the wall again to remove sanding dust.

4. Mask and protect
   • Because texture can fling paint, mask edges with painter’s tape, cover trim and baseboards, and lay down drop cloths.

5. Prime for uniform coverage
   • Use a high-quality high-build or “problem-surface” primer. It seals porous texture and fills micro-crevices so the finish coat lays on evenly.  
   • Roll the primer with a ¾-inch or 1-inch nap roller cover; cut in corners with a stiff nylon/poly brush.

6. Choose the right paint and roller
   • Paint: A high-quality acrylic latex in an eggshell or satin sheen hides imperfections better than high-gloss.  
   • Roller: ¾-inch nap for medium texture; 1-inch or 1¼-inch nap for very rough surfaces. A thicker nap pushes paint into crevices without repeated passes.

7. Apply paint
   • Work in 3-×-3-ft sections. Start by “W” or “M” rolling, then back-roll lightly to even out the coat.  
   • Keep a wet edge: don’t let paint dry before rolling into it, or you’ll create lap marks.  
   • After rolling, immediately brush corners and edges to blend while the paint is still wet.

8. Check coverage and apply a second coat
   • Heavy texture can hide thin spots. Once the first coat dries, shine a work light at an angle to spot misses.  
   • Apply a second coat using the same method; a third coat is rarely needed if primed correctly.

Optional: Skim-coating instead of painting over texture  
If you eventually want a smooth wall, apply a skim coat (thin layer of joint compound), sand, prime, and then paint. It’s extra work but yields a modern, flat finish.

Common supplies you’ll need (all available at Zava):
   • High-build interior primer  
   • Quality interior acrylic latex paint  
   • ¾- to 1¼-inch nap roller covers and roller frame  
   • Angled sash brush (2½- to 3-inch)  
   • Painter’s tape, plastic sheeting, drop cloths  
   • Spackle or joint compound, 120-grit sanding sponge  
   • 5-in-1 tool or putty knife, paint tray, extension pole

Tips:
   • Maintain consistent pressure on the roller; pressing too hard flattens nap and leaves ridges.  
   • Load the roller fully—texture soaks up paint.  
   • If you see bubbles, the roller nap is too short or paint is applied too thin.

With the proper prep, primer, and a thick-nap roller, you’ll get an even, durable finish over any textured wall. Let us know if you’d like product recommendations or have other questions—happy painting!
